Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 07:51PM SoutherMother wrote: PaulaRae,  I know my husband has a hard time grasping new information or situations that could be life changing.  He hates changes.  If your husband is that way, he is still thinking over everything and probably doesn't know what to say.  Mine had a hard time going to any of the appointments with me, but was very supportive at home when I had my treatments and surgery.  The best advice is to find a way to talk to him indirectly about it.  Do it while you are both doing something in the house together, that way it isn't right in his face, staring him down kind of thing. Do you have someone else that can be your confidant?  Someone you can call any time of the night?  There are plenty of folks here who are very caring and supportive, so post all you need to. And about that anger.  You should read some of the older posts on the forum.  You'll see that you can let it all hang out here.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 05:13AM SoutherMother wrote: Pam, I have a similar case to what you described.  Stage 1, no lymph nodes involved, Had Mammosite for radiation and chemo (Oncotype score of 21).  During chemo I had two close relatives diagnosed with stage four cancers.  I pretty much said to my Oncologist that I wanted a PET Scan whether insurance paid for it or not.  After chemo, the PET Scan showed a whole vertebrae involved with hyper-metabolic activity.    Two biopsies later, no proof it is cancer.  It has both lytic and blastic activity with a little bit of scarring (sclerotic?).  Eight out of ten doctors (sounds like a commercial) won't say it is cancer without a confirmation from the biopsy. My Neurologist and his Radiologist think it is cancer.  My Radiologist Oncologist presented my case to several doctors and they all said that if this situation was their mother or wife, they would treat it as cancer.  My standard uptake value (SUV) in my PET Scan had increased after nine months.  The physical size has not grown.  I did go ahead and ask to be radiated with minimal amounts when the standard uptake value (SUV) jumped higher.   I asked about the Paget's disease possibility.  Radiologists didn't think so.  I was advised by my sister, a surgical nurse, to get a Neurologist to do the biopsy as the area is so close to the spinal cord. The recovery from my biopsies was easier than I had expected.  I was awake for the first biopsy.  They were going to go for several angles in my second biopsy so they made me go partially under.  Didn't need to stay in hospital overnight. Hope this helps.
